content:
# Insecure Data Handling

## Description

The CORS policy in the Flask application is configured to allow all origins, which can expose the application to cross-origin attacks. This configuration allows any domain to make requests to the API, potentially leading to unauthorized access or data breaches.

## Vulnerable Code

```python
# backend/app.py

print("Loading environment variables...")
load_dotenv()

logging.basicConfig(level=logging.INFO, format='%(asctime)s - %(levelname)s - %(message)s')
logger = logging.getLogger(__name__)

print("Initializing Flask app...")
app = Flask(__name__)
CORS(app, resources={r"/*": {"origins": "*"}})
```

## Potential Attack Vectors

- **Cross-Origin Resource Sharing (CORS) Attacks**: An attacker can exploit this vulnerability to make unauthorized requests to the API from a malicious website, potentially stealing sensitive data or performing actions on behalf of the user.

## Recommended Solution

To mitigate this vulnerability, it is essential to restrict the CORS policy to allow only trusted origins. This can be done by specifying a list of allowed origins in the CORS configuration.

```python
# backend/app.py

print("Loading environment variables...")
load_dotenv()

logging.basicConfig(level=logging.INFO, format='%(asctime)s - %(levelname)s - %(message)s')
logger = logging.getLogger(__name__)

print("Initializing Flask app...")
app = Flask(__name__)

# Restrict CORS to trusted origins
CORS(app, resources={r"/*": {"origins": ["https://trusted-origin1.com", "https://trusted-origin2.com"]}})
```

By restricting the CORS policy to trusted origins, you can significantly reduce the risk of cross-origin attacks and enhance the security of your application.
